titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxvii — no.68 Richmond, Va. Friday, September 16, 1864 Price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.p:
The Daily Dispatch is sold to News Dealers at twenty Cents per copy.
City Carriers are authorized to charge one Dollar and fifty Cents per week to regular subscribers.

div3.head: The war News.
div3.p:
The "situation," in a military point of view, everywhere remains unchanged.
We give below such items of intelligence as were received yesterday:

div4.head: From Petersburg.
div4.p:
While the bombardment of the city was progressing on Wednesday, there was considerable skirmishing and cannonading in front, which, about ten o'clock, increased to a brisk artillery duel, gradually extending along the lines, and for two hours, from the right of the plankroad around to the river, an uninterrupted roar of cannon was heard.
The opposing lines of pickets have lately been more demonstrative than usual, and at times within the past two or three days the interchange of leaden compliments has been very frequent.
The shelling of Petersburg on Wednesday, as we have before stated, was one of the most vigorous bombardments of the campaign.
Shells of different sizes were thrown into the town at the rate of from ten to twenty per minute.
Mary little damage, however, was done.

The only movement of the enemy, perceptible within the last few days has been an advance of his picket lines, which have occupied a portion of the Vaughan road; and a corresponding advance has been made this side of the Davis house.

It is said that the object of the wanton destruction of the Davis house, on Monday, was to revenge the capture of so man. Yankee pickets at this point.
We do not see how the infliction of an injury upon a private citizen can compensate for the loss of men; but such is the Yankee mode of conducting the war.
Deserters report that the fifteen-inch mortar with which the enemy has been shelling the city recently, bursted a few evenings ago, killing twenty men.--The statement is doubted.
There was some shelling yesterday, and some picket fitting on the lines; but beyond this, nothing of importance occurred.

div4.head: The valley.
div4.p:
The Northern papers claim that in an action on the 10th instant the "rebels" were driven back with heavy loss.
There is probably no truth in this statement.
Indeed, we have it on the authority of a letter from an officer in General Early's army, that on that day the enemy was driven through Martinsburg, and on the following day our forces were engaged in tearing up the railroad.
Sheridan, however, is not so much to be blamed for claiming success where he suffers defeat, for of all the Yankee warriors he seems to have been the most unfortunate during the campaign, and it is not surprising that he should desire to shield himself from the odium that would follow a confession of the truth.--It will be remembered that he played the same game at the time he was whipped by Hampton's cavalry last summer, and succeeded in pulling wool over the eyes of the Northern people, who appear still to regard has as a great commander.

div4.head: Georgia.
div4.p:
There is no change in the position of affairs before Atlanta, nor will there be during the continuance of the armistice, which commenced on Monday last.
Even after that expires, there is an impression that there will be no resumption of hostilities.--Sherman will reenforce Grant, and endeavor to hold Atlanta with a small force; but no further advance is anticipated.
The Atlanta exiles who have arrived at Macon were in a most deplorable condition.
The Yankees are represented to have stripped them of everything except one change of clothing.
Such are the consequences of the enemy's success.
Georgia papers represent that our army is rapidly accumulating in strength and numbers, and hint at very pleasant rumors concerning our future prospects.

div3.head: Registration of Exempts and Detailed men.
div3.p:
The War Department has ordered the registration of all male white persons between the ages of seventeen and fifty years who are not now actually in the field or in the reserves, and also of all boys who will attain to the age of seventeen within the next twelve months, with the month in which they will become seventeen.
The grounds of exemption or detail will also have to be given.
Under this orders Captain Coke, the enrolling officer for this district, will proceed with the registration without delay.

div3.head: Additional from the North.
div3.p: Northern papers of the 13th instant contain no intelligence of importance.

The New York Freeman's Journal and News repudiate McClellan, and so does John Mullaby, editor of the Metropolitan Record, in a long letter reviewing his former acts of tyranny.
Mr. Vallandigham was at Columbus, Ohio, on Saturday, on his way to canvass the State of Pennsylvania, when he was met by McClellan's letter of acceptance.
He at once directed the Democratic State Committee to withdraw his name from all appointments, and returned to his home.
The Washington correspondent of the Tribune says:

q.p: Vallandigham immediately after reading McClellan's letter, telegraphed to a political friend here, "All hope is lost," and withdrew his name from the canvass.

div3.p: General Cass repudiates the Chicago platform as "an ingenious surrender to the rebels. "

There is no war news.
Stanton telegraphs that Wilson and Steadman will keep General Wheeler too busy to interfere with Sherman's lines.

Gold in New York has fallen to 218; but there has been no fall in the prices of provisions.
The people are not deceived by the temporary decline, and do not want to sell for greenbacks.
The steamers A. D. Vance, with four hundred and twenty bales of cotton, and Elsie, with three thousand bales, were captured on the 5th instant just out from Wilmington.
The captured privateer Georgia arrived at Beaufort, North Carolina, on the 9th, and would proceed to Boston.

The steamer Fawn, running upon the Dismal Canal between Norfolk and North Carolina, was captured Saturday by a party of rebel raiders and burned.
The crew and passengers were all taken prisoners.

The capture of the rebel guerrilla and raider, Quantrell, is announced to have been recently effected in Indianapolis.
He was there in disguise, and was recognized on the street by a refugee.
A report is in circulation at Little Rock, Arkansas, that the rebel Major-General Sterling Price died recently at Arkadelphia of dysentery.

div3.head: Later from Europe.
div3.p:
The steamship America, from Southampton on the 31st of August, arrived in New York on the 12th.
Her nows is three days later than the report of the Scotia.

The reports of General Grant's operations on the north side of the James river, when pushing to the Weldon railroad; of Sheridan's action with Longstreet at Front Royal; and of Farragut's victory at Fort Morgan, had been received in England, and produced an impression decidedly favorable to the Union cause.

It was rumored in Paris that the Emperor Napoleon would soon make another effort to intervene in American affairs, with a view to the ultimate recognition of the South.
The plan, it was said, would now meet with favor in France, as abolition was no longer an element in the Northern war policy, and as the Emperor had prudently waited for "questions to ripen. "

div3.head: Fighting Governors of the Confederacy.
div3.p: --Governor Harris, of Tennessee, is with the Army of Tennessee; Governor Smith, of Virginia, commanded a brigade and was several times wounded in the first three years of the war; Governor Vance, of North Carolina, and Governor Watts, of Alabama, have each served a campaign, and, we presume, "smelt gunpowder," Governor Clark, of Mississippi, and Governor Allen, of Louisiana, both "smelt powder" and were desperately wounded in the battle of Baton Rouge, not to mention the other actions in which they have been engaged.

Attorney-General Wharton, of Mississippi, has explicitly decided that foreign subjects residing in Mississippi are liable to militia duty, even though they may have taken an oath of centrality imposed on them by Federal authority.

Rev. Father Plimmel, a Roman Catholic priest, who has labored long and faithfully with his charge in the Army of Tennessee, was killed by a shell in the battle before Jonesboro', Georgia, on Thursday, the 1st of September.

Governor Watts, of Alabama, regarding the present extraordinary occasion, has issued a proclamation directing that the General Assembly of Alabama shall convene in the capitol at Montgomery on the 20th of the present month.

div3.head: The inside History of the Chicago Convention.
div3.p: The trickery of the Yankees at the Chicago Convention will be amusing to our readers, especially since they have read the sleight-of-hand letter of McClellan, in which he places the platform in a position described by the proprietor of the "little joker" by the professional ejaculation of "now you see it, and now you don't see it." From a very long letter in the New York Herald, written after the adjournment of the Convention, we find what the write calls an inside view of its proceedings.--We give some extracts, which will be found interesting:

div4.head: The strength of parties at the Opening.
div4.p:
When the delegates first came together there was a wide difference in their views as to a platform and principles, and each set struck to their ideas with great pertinacity.
At the same time each faction declared that there was too much at stake to quarrel, and they must harmonize in some way. The outside ultra peace element were much more persistent than the delegates, and endeavored to persistent than the delegates, and endeavored to press their ideas to the utmost.
It was this fact that weakened the peace element.
The cry was immediately started that they came have to break up the Convention and re-elect Lincoln.
The tide therefore soon turned against them.
It was this that shelved Wood and his pocket committee, that was not elected at Syracuse, and destroyed completely their influence for good or evil.

Vallandigham labored under the same difficulty, and was, with his backers from Southern Ohio, made powerless in the end. The war clement, which really composed a majority of the Convention on the start, laid their plans for a positive war platform; but on consultation it was found that a decisive and unequivocal move would strengthen the peace faction, and concentrate them into a strong faction large enough to make defeat certain.
They, with the moderate peace men, then directed every effort to secure the nomination of McClellan, who, they all agreed, the masses, east and west, clamored for. Finding that they could not get a platform to suit them without a split, their next dodge was to make the resolutions so general in their tone that they would not amount to much further than pledging the party to the integrity of the Union and its restoration, but general in their terms, and let the candidate be his own platform.
The public have already seen how they succeeded in this.
At least, the war element consider that they accomplished this point, and the entire Convention, with the exception of a few rabid men from Ohio and Maryland, jumped at it. It was adopted without calling the years and nays.
The only voices heard in the negative were from a few delegates from Ohio and Maryland.

div4.head: The fight in the committee over the platform.
div4.p:
The contest in the Committee on Resolutions was a severe one.
Vallandigham boasted that he had the committee with him at least two to one, But he soon found different, for the first contest that came up was in the election of chairman, in which he was badly beaten, sixteen votes being polled against him. As soon as the committee met, one of Vallandigham's friends moved that he be the chairman of the committac.
At this, Samuel J. Tilden, of New York, immediately opposed.
He, in a few remarks, paid a high enology to Kentucky, referring to her sufferings in this contest, and closed by moving that James Guthrie now be substituted in the place of Vallandigham.
This led to a spicy debate, which finally resulted in calling the roll, and each member of the committee voting for the person he preferred.
The result, as heretofore stated, was thirteen for Guthrie, eight for Vallandigham, and three scattering — just the reverse of what Vallandigham anticipated.
This was followed with a bitter attack upon his heresies by Guthrie, Tilden and other members of the committee.
Whilst this was going on, Vallandigham's friends flew about in a desperate rage.
In every quarter the cry was, "There is going to be a row." The bluster of these men on Tuesday night, when the committee were in session, was amusing, but to many alarming.
A free fight looked imminent.

Vallandigham not only insisted upon declaring the war unconstitutional, but his budget, as he urged it upon the committee, was in substance and meaning, when summered down to a point, an endorsement in full of himself.
Long before the discussion in the committee ended, Vallandigham was convinced to his satisfaction that he was a mere cypher there, and subsided.
He was decidedly let down, and the feeling was so positive in the Convention that he had to yield.

While this contest was going on in the committee, the New York delegation was called together, and an effort was made to instruct Mr. Tilden to advocate the adoption of the resolution presented at Monday's session by the committee, Mr. Tilden retired from the committee and took part in the dismission.
The real position, that a recommendation of an armistice in its legal, interventional and political bearings, was discussed, several of the leading men advocating it, and others opposing it, which ended in the motion for instructing Mr. Tilden being laid on the table by a decided majority, and the Committee on Resolutions then became the centre of anxiety and the point around which everything else revolved.

The contest in the Committee on Resolutions was kept up until two or three o'clock in the morning when nearly all of its members had expressed their views, when a committee of seven was appointed to draw up resolutions on which they could all agree upon.
This committee got together on Thursday morning and attempted to discharge this duty.--They found it no easy task.
With their efforts to get together, it was found that words meant too much.
The ultra peace faction finding that they were unable to get their ideas embodied in a straightforward way, labored for the next best thing that they could accomplish.
The other side, finding that there would be a bolt if they insisted upon a platform which perfectly suited their notions, went to work to make it as harmless as possible.
They had by this time become satisfied that McClellan would be nominated; all that they then asked was that the platform should not be so strong for peace that it would drive the war vote from them.
Never did men work harder than Messrs. Guthrie, of Kentucky, and Tilden, of New York, on this point.

One of the great obstacles in the way ws the use of words.
That of armistice especially troubled them, and a long contest was had in reference to adding a resolution interpreting its meaning.
They were unable to agree upon anything in reference to that point before the morning session of the Convention.
During that session it was directly charged in debate that a portion of the committee were purposely trying to delay their action in hopes of bringing about a combination to change the whole result of the Convention.
The indignation of the Convention to the idea that any portion of the committee would endeavor to accomplish that point was so manifest that they hurried up their work in time for the four o'clock session of the Convention, and brought forth the result that they did. It does not satisfy the extreme men, yet they finally acquiesced in it, although Mr. Long, of Ohio, Jones and Harris, of Maryland, denounced the idea of placing McClellan upon it to interpret it. They endeavored to make a point against McClellan on account of the platform not being satisfactory, and in some points objectionable to the peace men.

div4.head: The Struggle for candidates.
div4.p:
The Woods at first started off boldly, and were defiant.
They drew around them some of the ultra men of the West, and gave out in effect that they ran the machine.
The canvass of the vote of delegations was given, and two-thirds of the Convention were put down against McClellan.
But the question with these men was who they could concentrate the opposition to McClellan on. This was no easy task, for the crowd that hung around Wood were nine-tenths outsiders, and had no voice in the Convention.
Governor Seymour was finally selected as the man, under the belief that he would so divide New York as to effectually kill off "Little Mac."--Then came one of the wildest systems of bragging and false statements ever made.
The ultra peace blowers stationed themselves at all prominent positions in the hotels and related yarns of the strength of Seymour — how the New York delegation were about to decide to go for him — and ten thousand other yarns equally as false.
They had their effect for a time, more so than otherwise from the fact that a few persons who pretended to be Seymour's friends in the New York delegation gave credence and sort of endorsed the statements, while a large number of outsiders from New York were around offering to bet two to one that McClellan would not be nominated, and even that Seymour would be. This contest was kept up, with bitter assaults upon, McClellan, from Thursday noon until Saturday night. All of this time Seymour gave no public statement that he would not allow his name to be used; while, on the contrary, the rabid peace leaders were constantly asserting that he had told them with his own lips that he was a candidate.
The ultra peace faction concentrated their entire force upon him, and tried every dodge in their power to kill off McClellan with him. It soon, however, became apparent, by the way that they brought out other candidates held in reserve, that they, wanted to kill off both McClellan and Seymour by the move.
All this time the McClellan strength was slowly and surely increasing.
The fact becoming generally known that the ultra men were directing every effort to defeat him, concentrated the war clement as well as the moderate men on him.

div4.head: Scene in the New York delegation.
div4.p:
All at this time the New York delegation was the centre point.
It was on them that the ultra peace men relied for accomplishing their object.
Consequently no stone was left unturned to operate in that quarter.
But all their moves were boldly met by such men as John Kelly, of New York; Sanson, of Buffalo; Tilden, Dean Richmond, Delavan, Conger, Church, and, in fact, a large number of the delegates from the interior.
Mr. Kelly, of New York, took hold of the movement for McClellan with an energy seldom exhibited on any occasion.
Saturday night approached.
The New York delegation had fixed upon that evening to hold their in the main parlor at the Sherman House.
The excitement as the hour drew near was intense.
The approaches to the room were densely packed.
The delegation sat with closed doors.
Every person who came out of the room was seized upon by the eager and excited multitude to find out the result.
Betting was freely indulged in by the ultra peace men. For five hours the delegation remained in caucus, the intelligence now and then being conveyed to the outside that they were simply talking.--Finally a vote, which may be considered a rest vote, was announced on the question of tabling a motion of the anti-McClellan party, which.
was a triumph of two to one of the McClellan The debate, however, was continued.
among others, denounced McClellan and the arrest of the Maryland Legislature Green and others talked for Seymour some other man besides McClellan, but was not as bitter as some who preceded him, and thus the contest raged.
Governor Seymour finally took the floor and explained his position, announcing that some time since he had told his friends that would not be a candidate; that he was that the people demanded the nomination of the McClellan.
He gave as his reason for not refusing his name used here before that he supposed all knew his position, and besides, in up in a shape that he could meet the movements here.
He then replied to McKeen's charge upon "Little Mac," and gave McKeen a bitter rebuke, while he enlogized McClellan.
The impression of the majority of the delegation was that the ultra peace party were using Seymour's name for mischief.
He had no other course than to meet it, as he did in the delegation, by declaring that he would not have his name used.

The caucus broke up without taking a vote, Sunday was, therefore, another exciting day. The peace men all declared that Seymour had denounced McClellan, and that the New York delegation would vote for Seymour.
Again the belling commenced.
Several anti-McClellan men telegraphed to New York advising parties to two to one against. "Lattle Mac. " The ultra peace men every hour became more desperate, while the other side, conscious of their strength, remained quiet, and let peacetimes rave.
The canvass on the McClellan side, at a late hour on Sunday evening, gave McClellan; beyond all contingencies, fifteen votes more than two-thirds of the Convention.
They, therefore, about midnight on Sunday gave up all contest on the adoption of the two rule.

On Monday morning the again met and took a vote.
McClellan has fifty-five Nelson nine, Guthrie one, and one.
This announcement fell like a thunderbolt upon the peace faction.
Their cry then was, "We Seymour spite of the New York delegation." Towards night the peace men started the report that the New York delegation were going to meet and reconsider their action.

div4.head: On the floor of the Convention.
div4.p:
Thus the contest went on. The Woods, with the assistance of the bogus committee from Syracuse, and a few rabid men from Ohio, got up an anti-McClellan demonstration in the evening.
Schnable, of Pennsylvania, and several others of that stamp, undertook to make speeches denouncing "Little Mac;" but they were soon silenced and choked off by the masses assembled.
Thus foiled, Harris of Maryland, and Long, of Ohio, were then got hold of and were prevailed upon to denounce McClellan in the Convention.
This was the last resort of the ultra peace faction.
Upon that they based their success or failure.
Their dodge was to denounce him in every way possible, and to prevent a nomination on Tuesday, in hopes that, through the feeling that they might arouse against "Little Mac," they could secure sufficient change in front during the night to prevent his nomination.
They succeeded in preventing a ballot that evening.
Night having overtaken them, and there being no way to light the building, they were obliged to adjourn.

Then came the private manipulations.
The game of brag was once more commenced, but it did not avail them anything.
About midnight it became apparent that instead of weakening McClellan's strength it had the reverse result.
It concentrated and riveted it more firmly together.
The effect was just what the McClellan men wanted.
They were delighted with the idea of the rabid peace clement denouncing him, and considered the action of Harris, Jones and Long one of the best cards they could have before the people.

The charges of Harris were met by General Morgan, of Ohio, the gallant officer of Cumberland Gap fame, but the ultra peace men were only the more enraged.
Their game was to defeat McClellan's nomination at all hazards; but the result showed that they had undertaken a task which they, with the combined efforts of the Republican Administration, were not able to do. In the effort to make the nomination unanimous, about one-third of the Ohio delegation held out to the last, and refused to come in until Pendleton was nominated for Vice-President.

James Guthrie was the choice of a majority of the Eastern delegations for Vice-President, and on the first ballot he received more votes then any other candidate, and would have been nominated on the second ballot if New York had not changed.
It was represented to the leaders of the New York delegation that the nomination of Pendleton would heal all the difficulty in the West and Northwest, and be satisfactory to the Ohio ultras.
Guthrie had all along refused to be a candidate, and when Richmond was told these facts he said, " I want to elect the ticket; if the nomination of Pendleton will secure any more strength, then let us change. " Half an hour was given for consultation.
The Western leaders and those from the East consulted together, and the result was that New York changed to Pendleton.
Pennsylvania followed, and he was nominated.

div3.head: A Detective "Peppered" and
div3.p:
--Yesterday morning detectives John Reece and James K. Hix received information that there were three Confederate deserters skulking about in the vicinity of Clarke's spring, and forthwith repaired thither in search of them.
On arriving in the neighborhood the two separated, Reece taking one direction and Hix the other Reece had not proceeded far before he discovered the deserters ambushed behind some brush, and called upon them to surrender, whereupon they rushed out on him, and one of them threw in his face a handful of cayenne pepper, which caused him to clap his hands to his eyes, when the same man made a dash at his face with a knife, cutting his hands very severely and making a large gash in his cheeks.
The party then fled, and were fired at by Reece, though neither were struck.
Heating the report of a pistol, Hix went to the assistance of Reece, and was much astonished to find him bleeding profusely from his face and hands, as well as perfectly blind in consequence of the pepper which had been thrown in his eyes.
Reece's sufferings are represented as being of the most excruciating character, and he had to be led back to his residence, near Brooke Avenue, where, up to a late hour yesterday afternoon, he was still experiencing great pain and total blindness.

div3.head: Serious Rencontre.
div3.p:
--At an early hour yesterday morning the citizens living in the neighborhood of Shockoe Hill burying-ground were startled by violent blows and oaths, which, upon investigation, proved to emanate from a difficulty which had occurred between Jordan Miller, a man familiar to the criminal authorities of this city, and John Thornton, a member of the Reserved forces of the State.
Miller, having for some time suspected Thornton of an undue intimacy with his family, set himself to watch around his premises the night preceding, and, at an early hour yesterday, happening to discover Thornton in the neighborhood of his residence, he pitched into him with a club.
In the course of the melee both parties were dreadfully cut and bruised about the head and face.
The matter will be investigated before the Mayor this morning.

div3.head: Gone to the enemy.
div3.p: --Captain Knox, the defaulting commissary, and George W. Buttler, of the Treasury Department, who left this city Friday, succeeded, we learn from a gentlemen who came down on the cars from Fredericksburg, in crossing the Potomac Tuesday night, and are now safe among the Yankees.

div3.head: Confederate States district Court, yesterday.
div3.p: --The bondsman of Richard Hicks, charged with a misdemeanor, becoming alarmed lest he should fail to appear and answer for the offence, withdrew his bail and turned him over to the custody of the Marshal.
The motion for sequestrating certain property belonging to Urish P. Levy, an alien enemy, will be discussed on the 26th of September.
The following presentiments were made by the Grand Jury: Mary B. Yates and John Keagan, indicted for concealing and harboring Confederate deserters, and William J. Harwood, for trading in greenbacks.
The court afterwards adjourned till this morning.

div3.head: Hustings Court, yesterday.
div3.p:
--C. S. Jenes, late chief clerk of the Confederate States Treasury, indicted by the Grand Jury in three cases for betting at fare, was fined $1,000 and required to give security in the sum of $3,000 for his good behavior.--Robert Calivan and Charles Fitzpatrick, indicted in four cases for retailing ardent spirits contrary to law, were fined sixty dollars for each offence.--Nolle prosequi were entered in the cases of Patrick Foley and Maria Wade, charged with misdemeanors;--Nelson, indicted for violating the liquor law, and Antonio Emenheiser, for receiving stolen goods,--Joanna McCarthy, charged with misdemeanor, was discharged.
The following parties, indicted for violating the liquor law, plead guilty, and came forward and paid the fines imposed in such cases, whereupon they were discharged from prosecution: August Weimer, one case; Richard Emerson, one; John F. Chambers, three; Francis Beebee, six; Henry Smith, four; Thomas Phillips, three; Thomas Otey, two. Sixty dollars were paid for each offence, making in the aggregate $1,200.

div3.head: Mayor's Court, yesterday.
div3.p: --John Harris, white, Thomas White, and William Vaughan, free negroes, were called to undergo a continued examination on the charge of stealing a horse, valued at one thousand dollars, from Colonel Joseph Maye, of Buckingham county. Dr. John Maye, of Buckingham, testified that the horse belonging to his brother, Colonel Maye, was turned loose with his own horses in his private pasture; that he was stolen therefrom by Harris, and afterwards traced to Richmond, where he was sold to a Mr. Bass for eight hundred and fifty dollars. [The other testimony has already been published.] The two negroes and Harris were sent on for examination before the Hustings Court.

Horace Hovan, a youth, was charged with stealing one hundred and fifteen dollars from Mrs. Patrick Sweeney.
The charge was fully made out against the accused, but as in many other cases of a similar character, the extreme youth of the offender induced the Mayer to release him with an admonition.

Sum, slave of Richard Winslew, arrested without any pass, and charged with stealing a piece of beef, a chicken, and sundry other articles from the Winder Hospital, was ordered to be whipped; but subsequently, upon the representation of connect that he had already been punished for the offence by the hospital authorities, he was discharged.
A few other negro cases of minor importance occupied the time of the court — after which an adjournment took place till this morning.

div3.head: From Georgia--railroad accident — Arrival of the Atlanta exiles.
div3.p:
--A train leaded with Federal prisoners ran off the track last night at Camp creek, on the Southwestern railroad. Eight cars and the engine were crushed to pieces.
A large number of Yankees were killed and wounded, fully as many as were Confederates in their removal from Point Lookout to Elmira, New York, when a similar accident occurred.

Many of our officer, are of the opinion that there will be no further advance of the enemy in Georgia this year.
It is thought that Sherman proposed the armistice for the purpose of putting Atlanta in a condition to be held by a small force.

The first train of exits from Atlanta arrived last night.
They were robbed of everything before being sent into our lines.
There has been further correspondence between Generals Hood and Sherman on the subject of an exchange of prisoners, but no agreement has yet been arrived at.

div3.head: From Mobile.
div3.p:
--There is nothing new to report.
Seven Yankee vessels are lying quietly below the obstructions.

div3.head: Pious vandals.
div3.p: --The New York Christian Enquirer has the following rebuke of some of its less scrupulous brethren:

q.p:
"In several libraries of New England clergymen we have seen choice volumes, of great cost, hearing the names of Southern ministers, to whom they still belong, although they have been sent North as gifts from Yankee soldiers who had appropriated them.
Some Massachusetts parlors are said to be carpeted with spoils of another kind.
Now, if any one asks what has become of the Union party, once so strong at the South, we answer that , in part, they have been alienated from the Government by the unjustifiable on targes committed by wicked or thoughtless Federal soldiers.
At Beaufort, South Carolina, tombs were violated.
At Holly Springs, Mississippi, a communion false was used in behalf of 'euchre' and 'old sledge.' Such tales of wrong have infuriated many who were disposed to be friends of the Union, and their righteous indigestion has had something to do with reverses that have overtaken our arms."

div3.p: The Enquirer also quotes, with indignation, a letter from an officer, written at Camp Saxon, Beaufort, South Carolina, in which he says:

q.p:
"The splendid mansion once occupied by that arch-rebel, T. Butler King, is on a Georgia island, and we stripped it of everything.
I write this letter on his writing desk, which, with his plano, was presented to me on my return."

div4.p: On the 15th September, after a protracted illness which she bore with true Christian fortitude and resignation, Mrs. Lucinda Augustine, in the thirty-fourth year of her age.
The friends and acquaintances of the family, and of the family of Mr. D. Antelleti, are requested to attend her funeral, which will take place from St. Peter's Cathedral to-day at 10 o'clock.
At Chimborazo Hospital on the 15th instant, at 1½ o'clock, William Footey, of the Fifteenth regiment Virginia volunteers.

His funeral will take place to-day from the residence of his sister, Mrs. Mattie J. Hollins, on Jackson, between Foushee and Adams streets. The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Killed, on July 30th, 1864. Benjamin F. Crofield, of Company I, Sixth Virginia Regiment, Mahone's Brigade.

Our comrade fell near the "Crater," where so many of the good and brave were taken away.
He died with the shouts of victory sounding in his ear. Short has been this young soldier's career, sad the blow to his parents and friends; yet he has left them the hope that his "warfare is accomplished," his soul triumphing in death.
Truly, soldiers, though he will no more sit by our camp-fire, no more share our toils and dangers, let us hope to meet him in that better country where all is peace; and oh?
ye loving ones, whose tears are yet flowing for his untimely fall, remember that ye are but strangers and sojourners in this valley of sorrow and pain, looking forward with joy to the hour when he will welcome you into all the pleasures of the Glory Land.

div4.head: A Tribute of Respect.
div4.p: To the Memory of Robt. Ryland Walthall, of Company G, First Regiment of Virginia Infantry, who was killed at the Battle of Drewry's Bluff, May 16th, 1864.

This young man was the son of Christopher Walthall, of the city of Richmond, and though youthful in years, was a veteran of the First regiment Virginia infantry.
He was among the first to respond to the call of his State when she summoned her sons to take up arms in her defence, and entered the field with his regiment early in 1861.
And from the battle of the eighteenth day of July, 1861, when he first met the enemy at Bull Run, up to the period of his death, that patriotism and devotion which first animated him to take up arms never dimmed or diminished.
On the wearisome, long march, and amid the hardships and privations of the field, he gave evidence of the possession of fortitude and patience in a remarkable degree.
In his strict observance of military.
rule, no matter how minute, he showed himself to be the conscientious soldier, the man of principle, and yet the genial companion.--On the numerous battle-fields where his regiment has been engaged, he always bore himself with coolness and gallantry, and fought as the good soldier, and he whose arm is nerved with the conviction of right, always fights.

The want of space forbids the enumeration of the various battles in which Corporal Walthall had been engaged, and the part acted by him in each.
Suffice it to say, that he had been present with his regiment up to the time he was killed, except an absence of a few months, occasioned by a wound received at the battle of Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, and during that short period no battle took place.
Although his regiment had been actively campaigning, both winter and summer, since the first year of the war, the early part of last May found him with his regiment in front of Newbern, State of North Carolina; in that State be had just passed through a trying campaign.
He was called from there to the defence of his native city, and was one of those who stood at Drewry's farm, on the 16th of last May, as a well of fire, between their homes and household gods and Butler's army of vandals; and there, almost in sight of the spines of the city that gave him birth, while fighting for all that the true man cherishes most, he fell like the genuine soldier prefers to fall, (when fall he must,) righting in front of the battle, almost hand-to-hand with the foe, amidst the clash of arms, the rattle of musketry and the rear of artillery, when victory had already perched upon our banners and been sounded in his cars.

Thus was offered up another noble sacrifice upon the altar of his country.
We has comrades in arms, who knew his worth and many Virtues, mourn his loss and sympathize with his bereaved relations in their great affliction; but hope the probable transfer of him who had been so exemplary in this life to a better world and higher state of being, may prove their support and consolation.

div4.head: In Memoriam.
div4.p:
Death, the terrible and insatiate monster, has again been amongst us, and left a melancholy chasm.
He has tern his victim from the heart of society and from the altar of the living God.

On the 25th day of May, 1864, in the twenty-ninth year of his age, in the city of Richmond after a short though painful illness, died George W. Rady, in whom was found all that virtue, religion and philanthropy could desire.
It can be truly said of Mr. Rady, that his early youth foreshadowed an honest and upright manhood.
The good boy, made the good man. Respected, revered, and actually loved by all who were honored with his acquaintance, be unquestionably merited the well-earned reputation of one of "Netur's noblemen." A kind and affectionate husband, an indulgent and generous parent, a chivalrous friend and devout Christian, he proved himself a "saint on earth." Though dead in body, he still lives in spirit, and we console ourselves with the reflection that.

lg.l: "This sweet, as year by year we lose
Friends out of sight, by faith to muse.
How grows in Paradise our store "

div4.p:
A about last his minister asked him "if he was prepared to pass through the dark valley of death," and quickly received the triumphant response that "he feared nothing for the Lord was with him." The only regret manifested at leaving this world seemed the care of his wife and two little children.
May the Lord, in his infinite goodness and mercy, bless and comfort them in this his, and prepare them for a blissful with the husband and father in that

lg.l: How fair and how lovely it is to behold.
The sun, in its splendor, approaching the post;
Its race is near run, and refulgent at gold.
It glider through the other, as to rest,
Yet far more than this is the
Of a good man approaching the confines of time;
All loving, all peaceful, all calm and screen,
He passes away with a brighten sublime,
He dies, but pencil can order portray
The splendor and that his sight
As guided by as speeds on his way.
Through the portals of to the to light.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 27, Number 68, page 2.

div3.head: Rags Wanted.
div3.p: --The highest market price will be paid at this Office for all kinds of Clean Cotton and Linen Rags, in large or small quantities.
We find the following passage in an editorial article of Wednesday evening's Whig:

q.p:
"No that has been clearer since the commencement of this war than that the Yankees, above all other people on earth, know best how to magnify the slightest advantage into a complete victory, and to varnish over a rout so as to make it appear an insignificant repulse.
This was particularly the case in the account of McClellan's repulse on the Peninsula, Burnside's complete defeat at Fredericksburg, and Hocker's rout at Chancellorsville, to say nothing of the tremendous whippings (as the Yankee papers say) which our favorite Ulysses administered to General Lee in the battles and skirmishes from the Rappahannock to the front of Petersburg."

div3.p:
If the writer of this article had added that, notwithstanding all the experience we have had of Yankee mendacity, they are still able, by the most transparent lies, whenever we gain a victory, to make our people believe that it was we, not they, who were defeated, he would have told the truth.
Not three weeks ago the whole Yankee nation was in an agony of despair on account of the tremendous losses which they had sustained during the campaign of the spring and summer.
A small advantage gained by them at a single point elevated them at once to the seventh heaven of exultation.
The most enormous lies, the most extravagant boasting, and the most extraordinary efforts to create a public opinion in favor of continuing the war, were immediately resorted to. They had the effect which we foresaw they would have.
They created a perfect furore in the North, and cowed and intimidated us to a degree which we were amazed to witness, accustomed as we have been, for many years, to mark the fluctuations of public opinion.

And yet, upon reflection, the cause of this sudden despondency is easily understood.
The mind is never so deeply dejected as at the period which immediately follows an unusual elevation of the spirits.
The people had been indulging the hope that peace was near.
They were taught to believe it by those who should have known better; and believe it they did. That ill-omened Congress of self-constituted diplomatists at the Falls of Niagara first produced the impression, and, as it was an agreeable impression, it was impossible to eradicate it. We suppose a meeting of those three celebrated, but somewhat mythical, personages, the man in the moon, the gentleman in the claret-colored coat, and the individual who struck the much-abused William Patterson, Esq., would have had quite as much influence upon the issues of war and peace as the meeting of Messrs. Holcombe, Sanders and Greeley, neither one of whom, so far as we can learn, had any more concern in the matter than the three noted characters introduced in the first part of this sentence.
We endeavored to convince the public that it was so; but the delusion was pleasant, and they could not bear to resign it. Even Lincoln's notice "to whom it may concern" could not undeceive them, and it was quite useless to remind them that the two Presidents, by and with the advice and consent of the two Senates, can alone conclude a peace.
While the public mind was in this state the reverse at Atlanta took place, all Yankeedom was in a blaze of excitement, all ideas of peace were at once abandoned by our amiable foes, and nothing but blood and rapine could any longer satisfy their appetites.
Instantly the hopes of our people fell from the zenith to nadir; and as their expectations were altogether without foundation, so their dejection became utterly irrational.

The inconsiderate hopes which have been so largely indulged in this instance have had a very mischievous effect in directing the minds of men from the only subject which, at present, ought to occupy them, namely: the prosecution of this war with the greatest possible degree of vigor.
Nothing is so enervating as the disappointment of highly-wrought expectations.
Let us hope that these cries of peace, peace, at a season when there is no appearance of peace, will be discontinued for the future.
The Yankees must be defeated in their object so often as to learn that it is wholly unattainable, and that they are wasting their blood and their money in vain.
They will come to this knowledge slowly and much against their inclination.--But come to it at last they both will and must.--Even now Lincoln tells them that but for the two hundred thousand negroes whom he has stolen and converted into soldiers he should long since have been compelled to give up the war as a hopeless undertaking.
The negro soldiers, then, are all that stand between us and the attainment of our independence.
So far as these recruits have given us a taste of their quality, they do not appear to oppose any formidable barrier; and when we shall have removed it, such as it is, the war will be at an end.

Came to the Subscriber's, in the county of Caroline, Virginia, on the 1st of August, a Negro Boy. He cannot be induced to tell who he belongs to or where he came from.--Says his name is Moses.
Is about ten or twelve years old, black, and very poorly clad, and has the typhoid fever.
His owner is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges and take him away.

div3.head: One thousand dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on the night of the 10th instant, two Negroes, both mulatto or copper colored.
One, Armistead, calls himself "Armistead Fry," is about forty years old, with long hair, half straight and considerably grey; he is about five feet five inches high.
The other, a boy named Lewis; curly hair; very likely; and about seventeen or eighteen years old. They are supposed to have gone North.
Five hundred dollars each will be paid for their delivery to me if taken out of the county, or two hundred and fifty dollars each if taken in the county.
div3.closer:
George A. Sinclair.
Charlottesville, September 12th, 1861. se 15--3t*

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p:
--one thousand dollars Reward for my Carpenter, John Blackburne, delivered to me in Richmond.
He left Colonel R. F. Morriss's farm, in the county of Henrico, on the 1st instant.
He is about five feet seven inches high, quite black, very intelligent, reads and writes quite well, and is about thirty years of age.

div3.head: Five hundred dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my residence, the Carlton House, Sidney, the slave of Major J. J. Parham, of Tennessee.
He has been in my service since last January.
Last year he was hired as an officer's servant in the Western army.
This boy is a bright mulatto, of rather spare build, about twenty years of age; five feet ten or eleven inches high, without beard.
When spoken to, he usually puts on a stupid air, dropping his eyelids and jaw, and pouting his lips.
He pretends to a slouching gait, although brisk enough when he chooses.
He is a good hostler and fair cook.
When last seen at home, at 6 o'clock P. M., Sunday, the 11th instant, he had on a grey cassimere sack coat, blue pantaloons, a drab felt hat, and army cloth shoes, much worn.
Is supposed to have taken with him a heavy woolen drab oversack.
The above reward will be paid on his delivery to me in person.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, Va, August 26, 1864.
div3.p: Regulations for Carrying into effect the Act of Congress Approved June 13, 1864, Authorizing Owners of Registered eight Per Cent. Bonds, issued Under the Provisions of the Act Approved May 16, 1861, to Exchange the same for Coupon bonds.--Parties owning registered eight per cent. bonds under the act of May 16, 1861, desiring to exchange them for coupon bonds, will assign them, in the manner pointed out in the printed endorsement on the back of the certificate, to the "Confederate States of America, in exchange for coupon bonds, " and cause them to be presented to the Register of the Treasury Department, who will thereupon, in compliance with the provisions of the act of June 13, 1864, issue coupon bonds for the amount specified in the registered bonds so assigned.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America.
div3.p:
Loans on the Security of the five hundred Million Six Per Cent. Non-Taxable bonds, Under the Seventh Section of the Currency Law.--Deposits on call will be received by the Treasurer in this city, Assistant Treasurers at Charleston and Mobile, and the Depositories at Wilmington, Raleigh, Columbia, Augusta, Savannah and Montgomery, and certificates will be issued for the same, bearing interest at the rate of four per cent. per annum, and secured by the hypothecation of an amount of the above bonds equal to the sum of these loans.
The bonds to be set apart by the Treasurer, and the proceeds, when sold, applied exclusively to the payment of the said certificates.

The security and convenience afforded to banks and other corporations, and to the public generally, by this Rhode of temporary investment, and the effect of the measure, if generally adopted, in keeping the currency within moderate bounds, it is hoped will commend it to the favorable consideration of the community and secure their prompt co-operation in carrying it into effect.
div3.closer:
G. A. Trenholm,
Secretary of the Treasury.
Richmond, July 22, 1864. au 22--ts

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, August 8, 1864.
div3.p:
Certificates of Indebtedness Bearing Six Per Cent. Per Annum Interest and Free from Taxation. --By the fourteenth section of the act to reduce the currency, approved, February 17, 1864, the Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to issue the above certificates, payable two years after the ratification of a treaty of peace with the United States.
They cannot be sold, but are only to be issued to such creditors of the Government as are willing to receive the same in payment of their demands.
They must also be given at par, though free from taxation.

The attention of purchasing agents and disbursing officers of the Government is called to this class of public securities as offering peculiar advantages to those from whom the supplies of the Government are bought; and to facilitate the use of them, checks drawn by disbursing officers upon the depositaries holding these funds, and marked across the face "payable in certificates of indebtedness," will be paid in conformity therewith.
Depositaries are hereby authorized and required to comply with this regulation, and to make application to the Register for supplies of certificates as required.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, July 28, 1864.
div3.p:
Taxed Treasury Notes.--In order to promote, as far as practicable, the early liquidation by the Treasury of the Outstanding Taxed Notes, the Treasurer, Assistant Treasurer, and Pay Depositaries in the different States, are hereby authorized to receive the said notes, except the $100 notes, at 66½ per centum, on deposit, issuing for same certificates of loan, upon hypothecation of non-taxable bonds.
The said certificates to be payable on demand after the expiration of ninety days.
And all agents for the sale of the above bonds are hereby authorized to receive the taxed notes, with the exception above named, in payment of bonds, when sold, at the rate of 66 ½ per centum.
div3.closer:
G. A. Trenholm,
Secretary of the Treasury. au 22--ts

div3.head:
Quartermaster's Office,
Richmond, September 14, 1864.
div3.p: Wanted to Hire, for the balance of the year , ten Negro Teamsters.
div3.closer:
J. C. Maynard,
Major and Quartermaster,
Corner Ninth and Main streets. se 14--5t

div3.p:
Wanted to Hire, two good Servants; one to be Washerwoman and the other a Chambermaid.
Apply at the President's House.
